topics.body:
. . . . *UGGGGGGGGGGGGGHHHHHHH!*

So my mom just straight up won't listen to me about the cat.  Short version is that my cat, named Zack (yes I did name my cat after a FF character), got bit by a dog.  I'm listing all these things we can do for the cat to help him and she won't fucking listen to me.  Why?  Cause even though I'm 25 and have only lived in the same house for one year out of the past 6 she's still stuck in mommy mode and shit of "oh I'm the mommy I know better".  I know Zack is a cat, but I do have basic EMT training of "that shit looks fucking infected" and she's still stuck in "I'm the mommy of my baby therefore I know better".  It's a fucking infection on a cat that needs stitches; one of these days one of her cats is going to outright die cause she refuses to listen to me.

Side note: he's somewhat alright; tonight I'm getting liquid stitches and some saline and some other stuff to help him.  I obviously am not a vet, but basic stuff like this I do know.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
Do you ever have one of those moments where you're listening to someone brilliant say something incredibly dumb?

I know why people don't like TED talks now.
!http://i3.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/original/000/726/327/833.gif!


Some of the videos are interesting, but christ man.  The main problem with the videos is that they have a severe habit of making problems in the world sound extremely simple puzzles that a child can fix overnight.  Explaining problems in the world in a easy to digest manner is good and all, but that doesn't mean that you can idunno end the Syrian civil war overnight if you follow these ten easy steps(tm).
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54cd730863687226ac8d2700#post_54cd730863687226ac8d2700

From an outsider's perspective, any problem becomes simple when sufficiently analyzed but the mistake is thinking the solution one individual comes up with will also result with someone else.

It's not so much of simpliflying the problem as much as thinking the solution applied to everyone.
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4
